entry.et: Middle English, from Old English bēon; akin to Old High German bim am, Latin fui I have been, futurus about to be, fieri to become, be done, Greek phynai to be born, be by nature, phyein to produce

def.dt: :to equal in meaning :have the same connotation as :symbolize God is love January is the first month let x be 10
:to have identity with the first person I met was my brother
:to constitute the same class as
:to have a specified qualification or characterization the leaves are green
:to belong to the class of the fish is a trout used regularly in senses 1a through 1e as the copula of simple predication
:to have an objective existence :have reality or actuality :live I think, therefore I am
:to have, maintain, or occupy a place, situation, or position the book is on the table
:to remain unmolested, undisturbed, or uninterrupted used only in infinitive form let him be
:to take place :occur the concert was last night
:to come or go has already been and gone has never been to the circus
:belong befall

dt.un: used with the past participle of transitive verbs as a passive-voice auxiliary the money was found the house is being built
used as the auxiliary of the present participle in progressive tenses expressing continuous action he is reading I have been sleeping
used with the past participle of some intransitive verbs as an auxiliary forming archaic perfect tenses Christ is risen from the dead 1 Corinthians 15:20(Douay Version)
used with the infinitive with to to express futurity, arrangement in advance, or obligation I am to interview him today she was to become famous

def.dt: beryllium
bachelor of education
bachelor of engineering
bill of exchange
Black English

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English eom; akin to Old Norse em am, Latin sum, Greek eimi
Middle English, from Old English earun; akin to Old Norse eru, erum are, Old English is is

cx.cl: present 2d singular or present plural of

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English eart; akin to Old Norse est, ert (thou) art, Old English is is
Middle English frend, from Old English frēond; akin to Old High German friunt friend, Old English frēon to love, frēo free

def.dt: :one attached to another by affection or esteem
:acquaintance
:one that is not hostile
:one that is of the same nation, party, or group
:one that favors or promotes something (as a charity)
:a favored companion
:a member of a Christian sect that stresses Inner Light, rejects sacraments and an ordained ministry, and opposes war called also Quaker
:to have a friendship or friendly relationship with

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German ist is (from sīn to be), Latin est (from esse to be), Greek esti (from einai to be)

def.dt: :a person's self :one's own self used reflexively as object of a preposition or verb or for emphasis in various constructions
:one's normal, healthy, or sane condition or self
:to conduct oneself in a usual or fitting manner
